name: Defend - Abuse Mailbox Automation
title: Defend - Abuse Mailbox Automation
body:
Usually, organizations have mailboxes that can be used to receive emails reported as phishing by users to be investigated. Defend will monitor the specified abuse mailbox to see what is being reported by end-users and automatically remediate malicious and persistent phishing threats. Event notifications can also be configured to notify admins when specific actions have occurred regarding the abuse mailbox, as well as provide a feedback loop to users, ensuring they understand they are helping keep your organization secure.

Reported emails can be attached as EML files and sent to the abuse mailbox through a variety of methods:

  • Emails reported using reporting buttons on the email summary page
  • Phish alert buttons such as:
    • KnowBe4's Phish Alert Button (PAB)
    • Microsoft's report phish button
  • Emails forwarded as an attachment

Expand the sections below to learn more:

  • To configure the abuse mailbox, follow the steps below:

    1. Log in to your Defend console.
    2. Navigate to Settings > Abuse Mailbox Automation.
    3. Enter the address of your abuse mailbox.
    4. Use the Automatic Remediation drop-down menu to select whether emails classified as dangerous after reanalysis are all automatically remediated.
    5. Select which notifications are sent to users. The notifications can be sent for the following scenarios:
      • On submission
      • Benign reanalysis
      • Dangerous reanalysis
      • Phish text reanalysis
    6. Specify the email signature to be displayed at the bottom of the user notification emails.
    7. Select Save Changes at the top of the page.
    8. The Disabled status will change to Active when Abuse Mailbox is successfully configured.

    Note: To allow KnowBe4 to send these notification emails on behalf of your organization, you may need to re-authenticate to Microsoft 365 on the Settings page. The specified Phishing Mailbox address is used to send the notification emails.

  • Admins can monitor emails reported to the abuse mailbox in the Defend console. The Abuse Mailbox page displays the reported emails. Emails are grouped at a campaign level to aid efficient investigation and remediation.

    At the top of the page, the following statistics are displayed:

    • Number of submissions analyzed
    • Number waiting to be analyzed
    • Number of dangerous campaigns reported
    • Number of benign campaigns reported
    • The accuracy of the users sending emails to the abuse mailbox
    • Number of campaigns remediated

    There is also a filtering option to help you triage the data. You can filter by status or reanalysis results. You can export the data to a CSV file.

    The Abuse Mailbox Automation table has details on campaigns submitted with status tags attached that update dynamically as the investigation progresses. Clicking on a line entry will open a right-hand panel displaying further campaign details. You can also view the emails for investigation purposes.

    If you don't have Auto-Remediation enabled, the right-hand panel will allow you to remediate the emails in the campaign. All further instances of the campaign will be auto-remediated.

    Note: If you have added a phishing test entry to your Allow List, and a user submits the test email to the abuse mailbox, the email will display as Dangerous. This feature is because entries on the allow list bypass phishing test scanning algorithms.

  • The following tags may appear on your abuse mailbox page.

    Reanalysis Tag Description
    The email has been reanalyzed and is benign. These are usually spam or graymail emails that have been submitted by users who believe them to be a phishing email.
    The email has been reanalyzed and is dangerous. If you have auto-remediate enabled, this will be remediated according to your settings. If it is set to disable, you will have an Action Required status for you to review and remediate manually if required.
    Displayed when the abuse mailbox submission is awaiting reanalysis.
    The email has been reanalyzed and found to be benign with some suspicious elements, but not enough to be marked as dangerous. You can view the email to investigate further.
    Emails marked as a phishing test will help you ascertain who understands the risk to your organization.
    Status Tag Description
    The emails in this campaign have been auto-remediated according to your specified settings.
    The emails in this campaign have been remediated by you or another admin according to your settings.
    Displayed when auto-remediation is disabled, allowing you to investigate and remediate emails that have been found as dangerous on reanalysis.
    The email submitted to abuse mailbox is benign. There is no action required by admins.

  • Admin notifications can be configured for the following abuse mailbox triggers:

    • New submission to Abuse Mailbox email address
    • Abuse Mailbox Reanalysis updated to Dangerous
    • Abuse Mailbox Reanalysis updated to Benign
    • Abuse Mailbox Reanalysis updated to inconclusive

    For full details, see the Defend - Event Notifications article.

  • You can configure notifications to be sent to users in the following scenarios:

    • On submission
    • Benign reanalysis
    • Dangerous reanalysis
    • Phish text reanalysis

    Example notification emails can be seen below:



     

     

  • The abuse mailbox address needs to be added to Microsoft Defender to integrate the Microsoft phish button with Defend. Follow the steps below to configure this feature:

    1. Log in to Microsoft Defender.
    2. Navigate to Security Center > Settings > Email and Collaboration > User Reported Settings > Reported Message > Destinations.
    3. Enter the abuse mailbox address in the Add an exchange online mailbox to send reported messages to text box.
    4. Select Microsoft and reporting Mailbox if you want to also report the email to Microsoft.
    5. Select Save.

images.alt:
This image displays the configuration interface for the **Abuse Mailbox Automation** feature, highlighted with a "New" tag. The UI uses a dark theme with light text. All configuration fields include a help icon (question mark) next to the label.

**Configuration Details:**

The top section confirms the operational mailbox and current status:
*   **Phishing Mailbox:** Configured email address is `phishing@egress.com`.
*   **Status:** The feature is indicated as **Active** with a green checkmark.

The remaining settings are organized into two columns, detailing automated responses and remediation actions.

**Left Column (Automation Settings):**
*   **Automatic Remediation:** Configured via a drop-down selector, currently set to `Enabled`.
*   **Send user response for benign reanalysis:** Configured via a drop-down selector, currently set to `Enabled`.
*   **Send user response for phish test reanalysis:** Configured via a drop-down selector, currently set to `Enabled`.

**Right Column (Response Settings):**
*   **Send user response for user submission:** Configured via a drop-down selector, currently set to `Enabled`.
*   **Send user response for dangerous reanalysis:** Configured via a drop-down selector, currently set to `Enabled`.
*   **Email Signature:** Configured via a text input field, currently set to `Egress Security Team`.
images.context: change to Active when Abuse Mailbox is successfully configured.

images.alt:
This technical description details a dark-themed user interface dashboard focused on campaign analytics and filtering controls.

**I. Analytics Dashboard (Top Section)**

The top section presents five key performance indicator (KPI) widgets displaying aggregated statistics:

1.  **Campaign Submissions:** 227 Analyzed, 4 Awaiting.
2.  **Dangerous Campaigns:** 63
3.  **Benign Campaigns:** 15
4.  **Submission Accuracy:** 91%
5.  **Campaigns Remediated:** 86 Manual, 10 Automatic.

**II. Control Bar**

Below the KPI widgets, a control bar is labeled "Filters." On the right side, two action buttons are present:

*   **Filters:** A blue, primary button containing the text "Filters" and a filter/funnel icon, suggesting the toggle state for the filtering pane currently displayed below.
*   **Export:** A secondary button with a dropdown chevron, labeled "Export."

**III. Filter Configuration Pane**

The main filter pane is visible, offering granular control over the data displayed. Filters are organized into two radio button groups:

1.  **Status (with help icon):**
    *   None
    *   Remediated
    *   Auto Remediated
    *   No Action Required
    *   Action Required

2.  **Reanalysis (with help icon):**
    *   Dangerous
    *   Benign
    *   Awaiting Analysis
    *   Phish Test
    *   Inconclusive

**IV. Filter Actions**

At the bottom right of the filter pane, two action buttons manage the filter state:

*   **Clear Filters:** A secondary button to reset all current filter selections.
*   **Apply Filters:** A primary, blue button used to commit the selected filter criteria.
images.context: You can export the data to a CSV file.

images.alt:
This image displays a section of a tabular interface used for tracking security events, likely related to email or message processing, presented against a dark blue background. The UI lists 10 visible events, each defined by eight columns of structured data.

### UI Structure and Content

The data is organized into the following implied columns:

1.  **Event Start Time:** Timestamp in DD/MM/YYYY HH:MM format (e.g., `08/04/2024 12:05`).
2.  **Event End Time:** Timestamp in DD/MM/YYYY HH:MM format (e.g., `08/04/2024 11:49`).
3.  **Sender Identifier:** User or account name (e.g., `Manual Test`, `Ognjen Djokic (DevTec...`).
4.  **Subject/Description:** Text defining the content of the event (e.g., `Test quarantine issue`, `The Purge - Part X - F...`).
5.  **Total Recipients:** Numerical count displayed as text (e.g., `2 Recipients`).
6.  **Delivery/Processing Status:** Fractional status indicator (e.g., `1/2 Recipients`).
7.  **Security Analysis Result (Badge):** Color-coded status of the content analysis.
8.  **Remediation Status (Badge):** Color-coded status of corrective action taken.

### Key UI Elements and Status Badges

Status columns (7 and 8) utilize distinct color-coded badges to indicate processing results and remediation requirements:

#### Security Analysis Results (Column 7)

*   **Dangerous (Red Badge):** Indicates a high-severity threat detection (e.g., Rows 2, 3).
*   **Inconclusive (Yellow Badge):** Indicates that automated analysis was incomplete or ambiguous, often requiring manual review (e.g., Rows 6 through 9).
*   **Awaiting Analysis (Dark Blue Badge):** Indicates the event is queued or currently being processed (e.g., Rows 1, 4, 5).

#### Remediation Status (Column 8)

*   **Remediated (Light Blue Badge):** Confirms that corrective action has been successfully applied (e.g., Rows 2, 3, 4, 5).
*   **Action Required (Yellow Badge):** Correlates with Inconclusive analysis results, requiring immediate operator intervention (e.g., Rows 6 through 9).
*   **None (Text Only):** Indicates no remediation action has yet been assigned or taken for that event (e.g., Row 1).

### Contextual Observations

The log shows a correlation between status fields: events marked as **Inconclusive** in analysis are consistently flagged as **Action Required** in remediation, while most **Dangerous** events are successfully **Remediated**. Time stamps indicate the logged events occurred between 04/04/2024 and 08/04/2024.

images.alt:
This image displays a template for an automated email notification within a modern email client interface (likely Microsoft Outlook or a similar enterprise product). The email confirms the submission and analysis of a reported phishing attempt.

**UI Elements:**
*   **Header Bar (Top):** Includes navigation controls: "Close," "Previous," and "Next."
*   **Subject Line:** "Your phish submission is being analyzed - {subject}" with a dropdown chevron and a shielded icon, indicating a secure or automated message.
*   **Sender/Recipient Metadata:**
    *   **Sender:** "N" initial icon (green circle) followed by "Abuse Mailbox <[Redacted Address]>."
    *   **Recipient:** "To: You."
    *   **Timestamp:** Right-aligned, "Thu 26/01/2023 05:26," preceded by small action icons (Reply, Reply All, Forward, More Options).
*   **Action Bar (Bottom):** Contains prominent, clearly labeled buttons: "Reply" (left arrow icon) and "Forward" (right arrow icon).

**Email Body Text (Template/Placeholder Content):**
The body uses bracketed placeholders for dynamic data insertion:
1.  "Hi {name},"
2.  "Thank you for submitting this email, {subject}, as phish on {report-date}."
3.  "The email you have submitted is being analyzed and we will contact you shortly with an outcome."
4.  "Please contact your security department for more information."
5.  "Kind regards,"
6.  "{Organisation name}"

**Context:**
The image represents a system-generated confirmation receipt, typically sent to a user after they utilize an internal security tool (e.g., a "Report Phishing" button) to forward a suspicious email to the organization's security team for review.
images.context:
is
Phish text reanalysis

Example notification emails can be seen below:

images.alt:
This image is a screenshot of an email client displaying a notification regarding the analysis of a suspected phishing submission.

**UI Elements and Navigation:**
*   The header includes navigation links for "Close," "Previous," and "Next" (Previous is grayed out/inactive).
*   The email subject line is: "Phish submission outcome - {subject}".
*   Action buttons (Reply, Reply All, Forward) are indicated by icons near the date stamp and as labeled buttons ("Reply," "Forward") at the bottom of the window.

**Email Context and Text:**
*   **Sender:** "Abuse Mailbox" (with a blurred sender address).
*   **Date:** Thu 26/01/2023 05:26.
*   **Content:** The email body is a template response, utilizing several placeholders denoted by curly braces: `{name}`, `{subject}`, `{report-date}`, and `{Organisation name}`.
*   **Key Outcome:** The email explicitly states: "The outcome of this analysis has found the email to be **benign**." (The word "benign" is bolded).
*   **Purpose:** The email confirms the completion of the analysis of a reported phish submission and provides a security clearance status.

This image displays an email notification within a standard email client interface, structured as a template for reporting phishing analysis outcomes.

**UI and Context:** The top navigation includes standard email actions: "Close," "Previous," and "Next." The email subject line is "Phish submission outcome - {subject}." The sender is identified as "Abuse Mailbox" and the timestamp is "Thu 26/01/2023 05:26."

**Text Content and Placeholders:** The body of the message utilizes several technical placeholders (indicated by braces) to denote dynamic content:
*   Salutation: "Hi {name},"
*   Context: "...you submitted as phish on {report-date} has been analyzed."
*   Outcome: "The outcome of this analysis has found the email to be **dangerous**." (The outcome status is bolded.)
*   Closing: "{Organisation name}"

The text provides instructions to "Please contact your security department for any further information." The bottom action bar provides two explicit interaction buttons: "Reply" and "Forward."

The image displays an email notification titled **`Phish submission outcome - {subject}`** within a standard email client interface.

**UI Elements and Context:**
1.  **Header Navigation:** Includes `Close`, `Previous` (grayed out), and `Next` links, along with search and view options.
2.  **Subject Line:** Explicitly shows the subject line template: `Phish submission outcome - {subject}`.
3.  **Sender/Metadata:**
    *   Sender: `Abuse Mailbox` (represented by an initial 'N' avatar).
    *   Recipient: `To: You`.
    *   Timestamp: `Thu 26/01/2023 05:26`.
    *   Email actions (top right): Reply, Reply All, Forward, and More options (ellipsis).
4.  **Email Body (Template Content):** The text confirms the analysis of a reported email, utilizing placeholders for dynamic content:

    *   `Hi {name},`
    *   `The email, {subject}, you submitted as phish on {report-date} has been analyzed.`
    *   `The outcome of this analysis has found the email to be **inconclusive**.` (The keyword 'inconclusive' is bolded).
    *   `Thank you for your submission and helping to keep your organisation secure.`
    *   `Please contact your security department for any further information.`
    *   `Kind regards,`
    *   `{Organisation name}`
5.  **Footer Actions:** Two primary action buttons are visible at the bottom: `Reply` and `Forward`.
